image.altText: A mother and father holding their young daughter between them, smiling. They are standing on an apartment balcony.

items.synopsis: Medium- and high-density development in established suburbs is being spruiked as the solution to Australia's housing crisis. But there are still some risks.

title.children: Sean and Jane paid $720,000 for an apartment with no car parks and shared laundry. It was their path out of renting

image.altText: two photos of a filthy bedroom

items.synopsis: The disability royal commission found the abuse and neglect faced by two brothers was sometimes "mistaken for disability-related behaviours". Warning: This story contains content that readers may find distressing.

title.children: ‘Violence, abuse, neglect and deprivation of human rights’: Shocking details from Brisbane’s house of horrors revealed

image.altText: Promo image of a line chart showing housing costs broken down by income.

items.synopsis: Housing costs are at record highs, and we can show you who is bearing the brunt of the crisis.

title.children: Where you sit on this chart determines your level of housing stress

image.altText: a man standing in a garage charging his electric vehicle

items.synopsis: On a sunny spring day, Robin can fully charge both his and his wife's electric vehicles by lunchtime. It could be a big step on the path to net zero.

title.children: Could electric vehicles charge the way to a net zero emissions future?

image.altText: Vanessa Hudson, the incoming Qantas CEO, with model plane in foreground showing Flying Kangaroo

items.synopsis: With Alan Joyce announcing his abrupt departure from Qantas two months ahead of schedule, Vanessa Hudson is now in control of an airline with a reputation problem — and disgruntled customers say it will be tough to win them back.

title.children: New Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson faces an uphill battle to restore the public's faith as Alan Joyce departs

image.altText: Albanese stands speaking to media from a courtyard.

items.synopsis: The PM will use a speech to the ASEAN summit on Wednesday to release the government's South-East Asian Economic Strategy, a blueprint aimed at driving trade and investment north into the region.

title.children: Anthony Albanese starts summit season talking trade ties and regional security, with China in mind

image.altText: woman in garden

items.synopsis: Friends of Heather Scott say it is fitting her body will never be recovered from the idyllic northern NSW mountainside where she lived for decades.

title.children: Neighbours take comfort in knowing friend killed in landslide was claimed by mountain she loved

image.altText: A woman with blue shirt and name tag sits looking up at and holding the knee of a woman who sits on a raised bed.

items.synopsis: Australia has one of the world's best healthcare systems. But senior physician Fiona Reilly argues it doesn't always work as well as it should for patients.

title.children: It only takes 11 seconds for a GP to interrupt a patient. A simple shift could change things

image.altText: a shark underwater

items.synopsis: An inflatable catamaran was travelling from Vanuatu to Cairns when both hulls were damaged by sharks.

title.children: Three people rescued after boat attacked by sharks in Coral Sea

image.altText: A man looks on, waving his arms

items.synopsis: Spain's beleaguered football federation sacks the coach of its national women's team, Jorge Vilda, less than three weeks after he oversaw its World Cup triumph in Australia.

title.children: Spain sacks World Cup-winning women's coach as post-tournament chaos continues

image.altText: A small chimpanzee on a rope

items.synopsis: The three-year-old chimpanzee — whose surrogate mother rushed to his aid and refused to let go — is recovering after being bitten by the deadly snake in his enclosure at Rockhampton Zoo.

title.children: Gandali the chimp survives snakebite at Queensland zoo after mistaking eastern brown for toy

image.altText: A woman looking concerned

items.synopsis: A Queensland Small Business Commission report finds discretionary spending is still falling and the household savings ratio is at its lowest level since the 2008 Global Financial Crisis.

title.children: Households have been dipping into their savings to get by, but now those savings are starting to 'dry up'

image.altText: A large concrete police station with a sign saying Mt Isa Police Headquarters.

items.synopsis: A 35-year-old woman is in a critical condition while an 18-year-old recovers in hospital, after a man allegedly stabbed them multiple times at a home in Mount Isa.

title.children: Man charged with attempted murder, rape after double stabbing in outback Queensland

image.altText: young girl on bus.

items.synopsis: From war-torn hills and valleys, to the sheep and wheat paddocks of remote Australia, the Karen people are determined to pass down their language and traditions to the next generation.

title.children: Why Karen refugees living in remote Australia finally feel hopeful for the future

image.altText: premier annastacia palaszczuk at a vigil at night speaking into a microphone, a bright light is shining beside her

items.synopsis: Annastacia Palaszczuk has been a favourite topic of discussion at just about every media event held by Queensland ministers over the past week, despite the Labor premier being more than 15,000 kilometres away on holidays in southern Italy, writes Peter McCutcheon.

title.children: What's fuelling speculation about Annastacia Palaszczuk's leadership?

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: The latest GDP data is expected to show an annual slowdown in the Australian economy because of interest rate hikes.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Economy expected to tread water, Wall Street falls, Australian dollar tumbles

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ahead of today's June quarter GDP figures, Treasurer Jim Chalmers has warned of "substantial" challenges to the Australian economy. Economists are predicting the economy will have flatlined from April to June with economic growth predicted to expand by just 0.3 per cent over the quarter, and by 1.8 per cent from a year ago. The Reserve Bank expects the Australian economy to grow by just over 1 per cent this year. Mr Chalmers has told RN Breakfast that the global economy is in an uncertain place and China is slowing down. "We've seen, particularly in their property sector but also in relation to their retail and in relation to their exports, that the Chinese economy has been slowing quite considerably." "And that's obviously important to us." Mr Chalmers says the combination of China's slowdown and higher interest rates are putting pressure on the Australian economy. "The challenges to our economy are substantial." But Mr Chalmers maintained the government's view that Australia is expected to avoid a recession. Have a listen to the interview on RN Breakfast this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says China slowdown will hit Australian economy

featuredLink.title: Government 'welcomes' third interest rate pause in a row - ABC listen

children.content: Ahead of today's June quarter GDP figures, Treasurer Jim Chalmers has warned of "substantial" challenges to the Australian economy.
Economists are predicting the economy will have flatlined from April to June with economic growth predicted to expand by just 0.3 per cent over the quarter, and by 1.8 per cent from a year ago.
The Reserve Bank expects the Australian economy to grow by just over 1 per cent this year.
Mr Chalmers has told RN Breakfast that the global economy is in an uncertain place and China is slowing down.
"We've seen, particularly in their property sector but also in relation to their retail and in relation to their exports, that the Chinese economy has been slowing quite considerably."
"And that's obviously important to us."
Mr Chalmers says the combination of China's slowdown and higher interest rates are putting pressure on the Australian economy.
"The challenges to our economy are substantial."
But Mr Chalmers maintained the government's view that Australia is expected to avoid a recession.
Have a listen to the interview on RN Breakfast this morning.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market is in the red in early trade after a fall on Wall Street overnight. The ASX 200 index has lost 0.2 per cent with a mixed performance in early trade. Consumer staples and utilities are leading the losses, while energy stocks are higher after a rise in oil prices overnight. ASX 200 movers: Brainchip: +1.6% BlueScope Steel: +1.2% Beach Energy: +0.6% Amcor: -2.7% Capricorn Metals: -2.6% Evolution Mining: -1.9%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower

children.content: The Australian share market is in the red in early trade after a fall on Wall Street overnight.
The ASX 200 index has lost 0.2 per cent with a mixed performance in early trade.
Consumer staples and utilities are leading the losses, while energy stocks are higher after a rise in oil prices overnight.
ASX 200 movers:
Brainchip: +1.6%
BlueScope Steel: +1.2%
Beach Energy: +0.6%
Amcor: -2.7%
Capricorn Metals: -2.6%
Evolution Mining: -1.9%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder is under pressure to depart the airline after former chief executive Alan Joyce left the firm two months early. Qantas is mired in controversy, facing lawsuits over flight credits and cancelled flights, and caught up in the political storm over the federal government's decision to reject Qatar Airways' application for more flights into Australia. Qantas lobbied the government to block the plan, but the government has denied they were protecting the airline. And there's increasing calls for Qantas to claw back multi-million-dollar bonuses granted to Alan Joyce. Here's more from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan on the AM program. And Peter also takes a look at Alan Joyce's ups and downs for the ABC News Daily podcast.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Call for Qantas chairman to step down

featuredLink.title: Alan Joyce’s rush for the emergency exit - ABC listen

children.content: Qantas chairman Richard Goyder is under pressure to depart the airline after former chief executive Alan Joyce left the firm two months early.
Qantas is mired in controversy, facing lawsuits over flight credits and cancelled flights, and caught up in the political storm over the federal government's decision to reject
Qatar Airways'
application for more flights into Australia.
Qantas lobbied the government to block the plan, but the government has denied they were protecting the airline.
And there's increasing calls for Qantas to claw back multi-million-dollar bonuses granted to Alan Joyce.
Here's more from senior business correspondent Peter Ryan on the AM program.
And Peter also takes a look at Alan Joyce's ups and downs for the ABC News Daily podcast.

image.altText: A man in handcuffs

image.altText: A woman with a tan jumper and long brown hair leans on a wooden pole on her front porch, looking out to the distance.

image.altText: A computer screen showing Chinese company Baidu AI chatbot generating image of cat.

image.altText: A middle-aged white man in a suit with a yellow tie and glasses yells and points while speaking in parliament.

items.synopsis: Shadow Transport Minister Bridget McKenzie has accused the government of stifling competition by banning 21 additional Qatar Airways flights into major capital cities each week.

image.altText: Coco Gauff clenches her fist

image.altText: A German tennis player looks off to the side of the court as he cups his hand to his ear as if to hear what is being said.

image.altText: A koala sits on the edge of a nursery table near a wooden post, looking towards a nearby collection of seedlings.

items.synopsis: After several months of illicit gorging at a NSW nursery, Claude the koala has been caught in the act.
